title: 107_hr4891
content: The "Equal Surety Bond Opportunity Act" is the short title of the Act. It outlines the requirements for equal surety bond opportunities. The "Equal Surety Bond Opportunity Act" prohibits discrimination by any surety in any aspect of a surety bond transaction based on various factors such as race, color, religion, national origin, sex, marital status, sexual orientation, disability, or age. Discrimination is also prohibited if the applicant has previously obtained a bond through certain authorized programs. The "Equal Surety Bond Opportunity Act" prohibits discrimination by any surety in any aspect of a surety bond transaction based on factors such as race, color, religion, national origin, sex, marital status, sexual orientation, disability, or age. It is not considered discrimination for a surety to inquire about marital status, age, or previous bonding history for the purpose of determining bondability. The "Equal Surety Bond Opportunity Act" prohibits discrimination in surety bond transactions based on various factors. An applicant cannot be penalized for obtaining a bond through specific programs. Refusing to issue a bond under certain authorized programs does not constitute discrimination. The "Equal Surety Bond Opportunity Act" prohibits discrimination in surety bond transactions based on various factors. Sureties must notify applicants of their decision within 10 days of receiving the application. The "Equal Surety Bond Opportunity Act" requires sureties to provide a statement of reasons to applicants for adverse actions taken against them. This must be done within 10 days of receiving the application, with a possible 10-day extension if no bond has been issued in the past year. The "Equal Surety Bond Opportunity Act" mandates that sureties must provide a written notification of adverse action to applicants, including the right to request a statement of reasons within 30 days. Oral statements are allowed, with the option to confirm in writing upon request. The "Equal Surety Bond Opportunity Act" requires sureties to provide specific reasons for adverse actions taken, whether directly or indirectly through a third party. In cases where sureties accept few applications, oral statements or notifications may suffice. The "Equal Surety Bond Opportunity Act" defines adverse action as a denial of a bond, change in terms, or refusal to issue a bond as requested. It does not include refusal to issue an additional bond if the applicant is in default or exceeds a bonding limit. SEC. 3. CIVIL LIABILITY. Any surety failing to comply with section 2(a) is liable for actual damages to the applicant and may face injunction or other equitable relief as determined by the court. Actions under this section can be brought within 1 year of the violation. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATIVE ENFORCEMENT. A company must maintain full compliance with the Equal Surety Bond Opportunity Act to be approved as a surety by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Act requires a signed statement of compliance with the Act by the president and secretary of the corporation. The Equal Surety Bond Opportunity Act requires full compliance for approval as a surety by the Secretary of the Treasury. This includes a signed statement of compliance by the president and secretary of the corporation, as well as quarterly reports. The Act also grants enforcement authority to the Secretary of the Treasury. The Secretary of the Treasury has the authority to enforce the Equal Surety Bond Opportunity Act, including the ability to reauthorize a surety corporation after a 1-year period following revocation for noncompliance. The Equal Surety Bond Opportunity Act allows the Secretary of the Treasury to revoke surety bonds for nonpayment of judgments related to noncompliance with the Act. Amendments are made to sections 9304 and 9305 of title 31, United States Code, to enforce compliance with the Act. The Equal Surety Bond Opportunity Act empowers the Secretary of the Treasury to create necessary regulations for its enforcement within a year of enactment. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE. Sections 2(d) and 4(a) will take effect either upon the initial regulations prescribed under section 4(d) or at the end of a 1-year period from the enactment of this Act.
